sentence: The surface roughness of the fibre may be affected by the fibre extraction methods, and particularly the quality of the retting process (Figure 1a,b).

The size of the lumen may represent only a small part of the cross-sectional area, as in the case of flax (Figure 1c) and hemp, or in contrast it may represent a significant part for kenaf and wood (Figure 1d,e) [27].
As far as plant-derived fibres are concerned, their cross-section is generally polygonal, as evidenced for flax in Figure 1c.
Such cross-sections make it possible to achieve high fibre volume fractions within plant structures (see Figure 1c), such as stems.
Indeed, in the case of imperfect retting, residues of middle lamellae (Figure 1b) are present on the surface of the extracted fibres.

Mechanism
Dominant in
Secondary in



Fibre/filament

cell wall/lumen collapse (fibre cross-section deformation)



all plant fibre preforms

yarn cross-section deformation

void condensation (i.e., closing gaps between fibres)

Open in a new tabAs shown in Figure 2, plant fibre preforms experience all the compaction mechanisms that synthetic fibre preforms experience (described in Table 1), but not vice versa.
This is illustrated in Figure 3.

Image by the author DUS. (b) Fibre bending and flattening and void consolidation in a random mat wood fibre composite [40]; image reproduced with permission from © 2004 Wiley. (c) Yarn cross-section deformation and flattening and nesting–packing in a woven flax composite [43].Figure 3.
Reproduced with permission from © 2011 Sage.Lundquist et al. [40] found that lumen compression occurred at fibre volume fractions of 34% to 69% in wood pulp random mat preforms (Figure 3).
Francucci et al. [13] have also observed such irreversible transverse cell wall deformation in compacted woven jute fabrics, and this phenomenon increased as the fibre content increased (Figure 3).

This is in stark contrast with the observation of Lundquist et al. [40] (Figure 3), where all wood pulp lumen had collapsed by vf = 69%, and the wood pulp random mat was compressed further up to vf = 90%.

The limited research on permeability studies of natural fibre reinforcements shows that while plant fibre reinforcement exhibit higher permeability than glass fibre reinforcements (Figure 4) [17,23], wood fibre mats exhibit significantly lower (by about two orders of magnitude) permeability than glass fibre mats [46].
Permeability can be experimentally measured by tracking the progression of the fluid flow front and monitoring the pressure field (Figure 5).
A 1D unidirectional flow achieved through line gate injection (Figure 5a,b) is commonly used.
However, a 2D radial flow achieved through central injection (Figure 5c,d) may be more appropriate for anisotropic reinforcements to quickly measure anisotropy in permeability.
The flow front can be tracked manually (e.g., with scale bars, as in Figure 5b), with a video camera, or through pressure sensors.

For a demonstration, Figure 6a shows the linear relationship between the square of the flow front position and the fill time for two separate infusion conditions; the slope of the curve x2/t is used as an input in Equation (3) to determine Kunsat.



(2)



(3)

Figure 6.

Adapted from [24], with permission from © 2010, Elsevier. (a) Plot of square of flow front position with times for different infusion conditions (related to Darcy’s law). (b) Plot of saturated and unsaturated permeability against porosity (= 1 – fibre volume fraction) (related to the Carman–Kozeny equation).The saturated and unsaturated permeability can then be determined over various conditions, for example varying fabric porosities (or fibre volume fraction), as shown in Figure 6b.
Indeed, such concerns have been voiced in studies on the mould filling process of plant fibre reinforcements as well (Figure 7) [6,23,24,25].

As Figure 8 highlights, at low flow velocities (and high fibre volume fractions) capillary flow dominates, leading to inter-yarn voids, while at high flow velocities (and low fibre volume fractions) viscous flow dominates, leading to intra-yarn voids.
Both effects have been shown for plant fibre composites (Figure 8) as a function of the fibre volume fraction [41,63].
A flow simulation of the lower part is illustrated in Figure 9.

This argument is further strengthened by the fact that the difference between the saturated and unsaturated permeability vanishes with increasing porosity (decreasing fibre volume fraction) (Figure 6).
In fact, at very high porosity (ϕ > 0.8), Ksat/Kunsat < 1 (Figure 6).
The surface roughness of the fibre may be affected by the fibre extraction methods, and particularly the quality of the retting process (Figure 1a,b).

The size of the lumen may represent only a small part of the cross-sectional area, as in the case of flax (Figure 1c) and hemp, or in contrast it may represent a significant part for kenaf and wood (Figure 1d,e) [27].
As far as plant-derived fibres are concerned, their cross-section is generally polygonal, as evidenced for flax in Figure 1c.
Such cross-sections make it possible to achieve high fibre volume fractions within plant structures (see Figure 1c), such as stems.
Indeed, in the case of imperfect retting, residues of middle lamellae (Figure 1b) are present on the surface of the extracted fibres.

The surface roughness of the fibre may be affected by the fibre extraction methods, and particularly the quality of the retting process (Figure 1a,b).

The size of the lumen may represent only a small part of the cross-sectional area, as in the case of flax (Figure 1c) and hemp, or in contrast it may represent a significant part for kenaf and wood (Figure 1d,e) [27].
As far as plant-derived fibres are concerned, their cross-section is generally polygonal, as evidenced for flax in Figure 1c.
Such cross-sections make it possible to achieve high fibre volume fractions within plant structures (see Figure 1c), such as stems.
Indeed, in the case of imperfect retting, residues of middle lamellae (Figure 1b) are present on the surface of the extracted fibres.

This is illustrated in Figure 3.

Image by the author DUS. (b) Fibre bending and flattening and void consolidation in a random mat wood fibre composite [40]; image reproduced with permission from © 2004 Wiley. (c) Yarn cross-section deformation and flattening and nesting–packing in a woven flax composite [43].Figure 3.
Reproduced with permission from © 2011 Sage.Lundquist et al. [40] found that lumen compression occurred at fibre volume fractions of 34% to 69% in wood pulp random mat preforms (Figure 3).
Francucci et al. [13] have also observed such irreversible transverse cell wall deformation in compacted woven jute fabrics, and this phenomenon increased as the fibre content increased (Figure 3).

This is in stark contrast with the observation of Lundquist et al. [40] (Figure 3), where all wood pulp lumen had collapsed by vf = 69%, and the wood pulp random mat was compressed further up to vf = 90%.

The limited research on permeability studies of natural fibre reinforcements shows that while plant fibre reinforcement exhibit higher permeability than glass fibre reinforcements (Figure 4) [17,23], wood fibre mats exhibit significantly lower (by about two orders of magnitude) permeability than glass fibre mats [46].
Permeability can be experimentally measured by tracking the progression of the fluid flow front and monitoring the pressure field (Figure 5).
A 1D unidirectional flow achieved through line gate injection (Figure 5a,b) is commonly used.
However, a 2D radial flow achieved through central injection (Figure 5c,d) may be more appropriate for anisotropic reinforcements to quickly measure anisotropy in permeability.
The flow front can be tracked manually (e.g., with scale bars, as in Figure 5b), with a video camera, or through pressure sensors.

For a demonstration, Figure 6a shows the linear relationship between the square of the flow front position and the fill time for two separate infusion conditions; the slope of the curve x2/t is used as an input in Equation (3) to determine Kunsat.

Indeed, such concerns have been voiced in studies on the mould filling process of plant fibre reinforcements as well (Figure 7) [6,23,24,25].

As Figure 8 highlights, at low flow velocities (and high fibre volume fractions) capillary flow dominates, leading to inter-yarn voids, while at high flow velocities (and low fibre volume fractions) viscous flow dominates, leading to intra-yarn voids.
Both effects have been shown for plant fibre composites (Figure 8) as a function of the fibre volume fraction [41,63].
A flow simulation of the lower part is illustrated in Figure 9.

This argument is further strengthened by the fact that the difference between the saturated and unsaturated permeability vanishes with increasing porosity (decreasing fibre volume fraction) (Figure 6).
In fact, at very high porosity (ϕ > 0.8), Ksat/Kunsat < 1 (Figure 6).

As far as plant-derived fibres are concerned, their cross-section is generally polygonal, as evidenced for flax in Figure 1c.
Such cross-sections make it possible to achieve high fibre volume fractions within plant structures (see Figure 1c), such as stems.
Indeed, in the case of imperfect retting, residues of middle lamellae (Figure 1b) are present on the surface of the extracted fibres.

Francucci et al. [13] have also observed such irreversible transverse cell wall deformation in compacted woven jute fabrics, and this phenomenon increased as the fibre content increased (Figure 3).

As shown in Figure 2, plant fibre preforms experience all the compaction mechanisms that synthetic fibre preforms experience (described in Table 1), but not vice versa.
This is illustrated in Figure 3.
Lundquist et al. [40] found that lumen compression occurred at fibre volume fractions of 34% to 69% in wood pulp random mat preforms (Figure 3).
Francucci et al. [13] have also observed such irreversible transverse cell wall deformation in compacted woven jute fabrics, and this phenomenon increased as the fibre content increased (Figure 3).

This is in stark contrast with the observation of Lundquist et al. [40] (Figure 3), where all wood pulp lumen had collapsed by vf = 69%, and the wood pulp random mat was compressed further up to vf = 90%.

The limited research on permeability studies of natural fibre reinforcements shows that while plant fibre reinforcement exhibit higher permeability than glass fibre reinforcements (Figure 4) [17,23], wood fibre mats exhibit significantly lower (by about two orders of magnitude) permeability than glass fibre mats [46].

The limited research on permeability studies of natural fibre reinforcements shows that while plant fibre reinforcement exhibit higher permeability than glass fibre reinforcements (Figure 4) [17,23], wood fibre mats exhibit significantly lower (by about two orders of magnitude) permeability than glass fibre mats [46].
Permeability can be experimentally measured by tracking the progression of the fluid flow front and monitoring the pressure field (Figure 5).
A 1D unidirectional flow achieved through line gate injection (Figure 5a,b) is commonly used.
However, a 2D radial flow achieved through central injection (Figure 5c,d) may be more appropriate for anisotropic reinforcements to quickly measure anisotropy in permeability.
The flow front can be tracked manually (e.g., with scale bars, as in Figure 5b), with a video camera, or through pressure sensors.

For a demonstration, Figure 6a shows the linear relationship between the square of the flow front position and the fill time for two separate infusion conditions; the slope of the curve x2/t is used as an input in Equation (3) to determine Kunsat.

Indeed, such concerns have been voiced in studies on the mould filling process of plant fibre reinforcements as well (Figure 7) [6,23,24,25].

As Figure 8 highlights, at low flow velocities (and high fibre volume fractions) capillary flow dominates, leading to inter-yarn voids, while at high flow velocities (and low fibre volume fractions) viscous flow dominates, leading to intra-yarn voids.
Both effects have been shown for plant fibre composites (Figure 8) as a function of the fibre volume fraction [41,63].
A flow simulation of the lower part is illustrated in Figure 9.

This argument is further strengthened by the fact that the difference between the saturated and unsaturated permeability vanishes with increasing porosity (decreasing fibre volume fraction) (Figure 6).
In fact, at very high porosity (ϕ > 0.8), Ksat/Kunsat < 1 (Figure 6).
